articles.headline: Extremist Imam Tests F.B.I. and the Limits of the Law
articles.snippet: Suleiman Anwar Bengharsa has endorsed ISIS and is suspected of plotting violence on its behalf. But there is no clear evidence that he has broken the law.
articles.abstract: Suleiman Anwar Bengharsa has endorsed ISIS and is suspected of plotting violence on its behalf. But there is no clear evidence that he has broken the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, Suleiman Anwar Bengharsa has served as a Muslim cleric in Maryland, working as a prison chaplain and as an imam at mosques in Annapolis and outside Baltimore. He gave a two-week course in 2011 on Islamic teachings on marriage at the Islamic Society of Baltimore, where President Obama made a much-publicized visit this year.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: A Peek at the Secret English Farm Where Amazon Tests Its Drones
articles.snippet: The e-commerce giant has big plans to use autonomous aircraft to deliver packages, and is testing the devices in rural England. We went to find them.
articles.abstract: The e-commerce giant has big plans to use autonomous aircraft to deliver packages, and is testing the devices in rural England. We went to find them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WORSTED LODGE, England — After hours of searching, I pulled onto a dirt track here in the rolling hills of Cambridgeshire and spotted a small dot whirring across the blue sky, gently swaying in the breeze as it steadily flew about 200 feet above the ground.

articles.headline: A Curious Plan to Fight Climate Change: Buy Mines, Sell Coal
articles.snippet: Tom Clarke, a nursing home owner, concocted a strategy to cut carbon emissions by gaining control of millions of tons of coal reserves and multiple mines.
articles.abstract: Tom Clarke, a nursing home owner, concocted a strategy to cut carbon emissions by gaining control of millions of tons of coal reserves and multiple mines.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRVIEW, W.Va. — The coal was piled about as high as it could go, spilling down to the railroad tracks and towering over the elevator shaft. A yellow bulldozer pushed the mound to make room for more. From a distance on this rainy day, the black heap looked like a giant whale about to swallow the mine whole.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Michael Wines

articles.headline: At a Loss for Meds, Venezuela’s Mentally Ill Spiral Downward
articles.snippet: Amid the nation’s economic collapse, psychiatric hospitals are running out of medications, food and other supplies. Thousands of patients are drifting into despair and psychosis.
articles.abstract: Amid the nation’s economic collapse, psychiatric hospitals are running out of medications, food and other supplies. Thousands of patients are drifting into despair and psychosis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARACAY, Venezuela — The voices tormenting Accel Simeone kept getting louder.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Is Seen as Helping Push Asian-Americans Into Democratic Arms
articles.snippet: Asian-Americans are identifying as Democrats at a quicker pace than any other racial group, and many Republicans worry this election is accelerating that trend.
articles.abstract: Asian-Americans are identifying as Democrats at a quicker pace than any other racial group, and many Republicans worry this election is accelerating that trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On paper at least, Asian-Americans seem like perfect Republicans. Many are small-business owners. Their communities tend to be more culturally conservative. And a lot of them, having fled oppressive Communist governments, found comfort in the Republican Party’s aggressive anti-Communist policies.

articles.headline: Jamaica, Long Opposed to Marijuana, Now Wants to Cash In on It
articles.snippet: After easing laws against the drug last year, the government is looking to create a “wellness tourism” with legal marijuana businesses at its core.
articles.abstract: After easing laws against the drug last year, the government is looking to create a “wellness tourism” with legal marijuana businesses at its core.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica — Jamaica has long bemoaned its reputation as the land of ganja.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and His Allies Struggle to Move Past Tax Revelation
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s campaign lurched between refusing to acknowledge that released 1995 tax records were bona fide to insisting that his not having paid taxes was evidence of his unrivaled business prowess.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign lurched between refusing to acknowledge that released 1995 tax records were bona fide to insisting that his not having paid taxes was evidence of his unrivaled business prowess.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his allies struggled on Sunday to move beyond the revelation that he might have been able to legally avoid nearly two decades of federal income taxation, putting new pressure on the candidate just as he tries to recover from a lackluster debate performance.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Next Big Tech Corridor? Between Seattle and Vancouver, Planners Hope
articles.snippet: American tech giants stand to benefit from Canada’s smoother immigration process, and Vancouver is looking to feed its own homegrown tech ambitions.
articles.abstract: American tech giants stand to benefit from Canada’s smoother immigration process, and Vancouver is looking to feed its own homegrown tech ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Seattle and Vancouver are like fraternal twins separated at birth. Both are bustling Pacific Northwest coastal cities with eco-conscious populations that have accepted the bargain of dispiriting weather for much of the year in exchange for nearby ski slopes and kayaking and glorious summers.

articles.headline: Google, Lagging Amazon, Races Across the Threshold Into the Home
articles.snippet: Google is unveiling its answer to Echo, an artificially intelligent home device that vaulted Amazon ahead of Google in a race to build technology that interacts as humans do.
articles.abstract: Google is unveiling its answer to Echo, an artificially intelligent home device that vaulted Amazon ahead of Google in a race to build technology that interacts as humans do.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Amazon introduced its Echo device in late 2014, Google executives were caught off guard. For years, they had predicted the creation of a virtual assistant that would answer questions or help accomplish tasks, and they focused on building that capability into smartphones and tablets.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: How Donald Trump Turned the Tax Code Into a Giant Tax Shelter
articles.snippet: If Mr. Trump’s pattern of generating losses and using them to offset other income has continued, as seems likely, it’s obvious why he has not released his tax returns: because he hasn’t paid any taxes.
articles.abstract: If Mr. Trump’s pattern of generating losses and using them to offset other income has continued, as seems likely, it’s obvious why he has not released his tax returns: because he hasn’t paid any taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now we know: Donald J. Trump racked up losses so huge in the early 1990s that he wouldn’t have had to pay federal or New York State income tax on nearly a billion dollars in income.

articles.headline: Colombia Peace Deal Is Defeated, Leaving a Nation in Shock
articles.snippet: Voters narrowly rejected an agreement, signed just days before by the president and rebel leaders, that would have ended the country’s 52-year civil war.
articles.abstract: Voters narrowly rejected an agreement, signed just days before by the president and rebel leaders, that would have ended the country’s 52-year civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A Colombian peace deal that the president and the country’s largest rebel group had signed just days before was defeated in a referendum on Sunday, leaving the fate of a 52-year war suddenly uncertain.
articles.byline: By Julia Symmes Cobb and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank’s Appetite for Risk Throws Off Its Balance
articles.snippet: Deutsche has cultivated bankers with expertise in cutting-edge financial instruments, but that could be a liability in today’s market.
articles.abstract: Deutsche has cultivated bankers with expertise in cutting-edge financial instruments, but that could be a liability in today’s market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global banking giants — think of JPMorgan Chase or HSBC — make a nice return by capturing their share of the trillions of dollars that course through financial markets each day.

articles.headline: On Twitter, Hate Speech Bounded Only by a Character Limit
articles.snippet: Founded on the ideas of openness and free speech, Twitter pulses with venom, much of it from pseudonymous accounts — the white hoods of our time.
articles.abstract: Founded on the ideas of openness and free speech, Twitter pulses with venom, much of it from pseudonymous accounts — the white hoods of our time.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you go by what some Twitter users have to say, it’s a wonder I can string together a sentence. I don’t know how I ever manage to get myself to the office given what a “dumb ass” I am — a Jew, no less, and someone who soils his pants out of fear of a Trump presidency. And if you don’t believe that last bit, someone using a pseudonymous Twitter account was kind enough to provide a graphic photograph of the supposed soiling, but not his or her actual name, because it’s just so much easier to hurl bile while cowering behind anonymity.

articles.headline: Tricky Goal for ‘Birth of a Nation’: Inspire but Don’t Incite
articles.snippet: Fox Searchlight has aimed a grass-roots campaign at churches, schools and pockets of political influence to ease the provocative film into communities on edge.
articles.abstract: Fox Searchlight has aimed a grass-roots campaign at churches, schools and pockets of political influence to ease the provocative film into communities on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The coming film “The Birth of a Nation,” which recounts a violent 1831 slave rebellion and includes scenes that evoke present-day outrage over fatal police shootings of black men, has been marketed as an urgent call to action.

articles.headline: Ailing Obama Health Care Act May Have to Change to Survive
articles.snippet: With plans too expensive and inaccessible for many, the law will almost certainly need to evolve. The election is likely to determine how.
articles.abstract: With plans too expensive and inaccessible for many, the law will almost certainly need to evolve. The election is likely to determine how.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fierce struggle to enact and carry out the Affordable Care Act was supposed to put an end to 75 years of fighting for a health care system to insure all Americans. Instead, the law’s troubles could make it just a way station on the road to another, more stable health care system, the shape of which could be determined on Election Day.

articles.headline: How Hillary Clinton Grappled With Bill Clinton’s Infidelity, and His Accusers
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton’s 1992 presidential campaign used aggressive tactics to combat claims about his extramarital conduct. Here is a look at Mrs. Clinton’s role.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton’s 1992 presidential campaign used aggressive tactics to combat claims about his extramarital conduct. Here is a look at Mrs. Clinton’s role.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton was campaigning for her husband in January 1992 when she learned of the race’s newest flare-up: Gennifer Flowers had just released tapes of phone calls with Bill Clinton to back up her claim they had had an affair.

articles.headline: U.S. Tech Giants Are Investing Billions to Keep Data in Europe
articles.snippet: Companies like Amazon and Microsoft are building data centers across the Continent in response to Europeans’ desires to keep their information close to home.
articles.abstract: Companies like Amazon and Microsoft are building data centers across the Continent in response to Europeans’ desires to keep their information close to home.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the battle to dominate Europe’s cloud computing market, American tech giants are spending big to build up their local credibility.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Trashes Nafta. But Unwinding It Would Come at a Huge Cost.
articles.snippet: Abandoning the free-trade deal with America’s neighbors would mean upending major industries and a generation’s worth of economic integration.
articles.abstract: Abandoning the free-trade deal with America’s neighbors would mean upending major industries and a generation’s worth of economic integration.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you buy an “American-made” car, you are probably buying a car that has an immensely complicated mix of components that were also made in Mexico and Canada. The same is true for many electronics, and advanced textiles like carpeting. The beef in your grocery store might be from a cow that was fattened and slaughtered in the United States, but that was very likely born across the border in Mexico.
